newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan oil product demand seen growing slowly - MITI.
newsitem.headline: Japan oil product demand seen growing slowly - MITI.

text.p: Japanese demand for petroleum products is expected to grow slowly over the next five years, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI) said on Tuesday.

Demand for gasoline and gas oil is expected to continue to grow steadily, while demand for fuel oil C is likely to ease as electricity utilities make greater use of nuclear power and liquefied natural gas, MITI said in its five-year oil product supply/demand outlook.
In the 1997/98 fiscal year which started on April 1, Japan's oil product demand is expected to grow 0.2 percent from the previous year to 247.7 million kilolitres (kl), MITI said.
A breakdown of MITI's forecast for domestic oil product
MITI said naphtha demand in 1997/98 is expected to fall 0.1 percent from the previous year reflecting weaker export demand due to the start of new ethylene plants in Southeast Asia.

Ethylene export demand to Southeast Asian countries is expected to remain weak after 1998/99, but domestic petrochemical product demand is likely to keep naphtha demand growing by an annual average of 0.8 percent until 2001/02, MITI said.
Kerosene demand is expected to increase 0.7 percent in 1997/98 from the previous year, reflecting a slight increase in the number of households, MITI said.
